author: AOL Staff
title: Off-road drivers were swept away by river, says man who tried to save them
text: Off-road drivers were swept away by river, says man who tried to save them A man who tried to save three men trapped in a submerged 4√ó4 vehicle said they were ‚Äúswept away‚Äù as they attempted to cross a river. Emergency services including police, ambulance and a helicopter attended a location on the River Esk near Glaisdale shortly before midday on Thursday. A 4√ó4 was recovered from the river by the fire service just after 3pm and three men found inside had died, North Yorkshire Police said. Chris Ford, who lives nearby, told the PA news agency the men were part of an off-roading group when they crossed a ford on Rake Lane. The river, swollen by heavy rain, swept them away and carried them around 400 yards downstream, he said. Emergency services have been dealing with a serious incident on Thursday (28 December) involving a 4√ó4 vehicle in the River Esk near Glaisdale on the North York Moors üö® Three men sadly died at the scene. More information is available here ‚¨áÔ∏è [https://t.co/KgxPhHATO4] [pic.twitter.com/AvDT3TiqCk] ‚Äî North Yorkshire Police (@NYorksPolice) [December 28, 2023] It came as Storm Gerrit caused flooding and travel chaos across the country throughout Wednesday and Thursday. Mr Ford, a firewood salesman, was called to the scene to help recover the vehicle with his tractor and found it fully submerged beneath the water, he said. He and two others used tractors to pull the 4√ó4 on to the riverbank, he said. Police said another man, who attempted to help those trapped in the car, was pulled from the river and needed medical treatment. Mr Ford told PA: ‚ÄúThere was a ford they were going over and they were swept down 400 yards. ‚ÄúThey were part of an off-road club. ‚ÄúI went down with my tractor. There was a couple of vehicles ‚Äì one parked up. ‚ÄúYou couldn‚Äôt see the (other) vehicle. It was 3ft beneath the water. ‚ÄúI helped get it out on to the riverbank with three other tractors.‚Äù Two other locals, Rosie and Andrew Dale, said they were with Mr Ford when he got the call to help. They said they saw several 4√ó4 vehicles pass their home in the direction of the ford shortly before the incident. Mrs Dale said ‚Äúnobody local‚Äù would attempt to cross the ford in the current conditions. The area is popular with 4√ó4 drivers, she said, adding: ‚ÄúIn the summer you get 10 of them at a time.‚Äù A spokesperson for North Yorkshire Police said: ‚ÄúLocalised conditions across our area are making driving hazardous. ‚ÄúRoads are particularly badly affected around the River Esk, to the north of the county, as we have seen with the tragic incident near Glaisdale. ‚ÄúThere was another incident at nearby Houlsyke at 12.49pm when a car got stuck in flood water and another at Kirby Wiske in Hambleton at 2.35pm. ‚ÄúThankfully, the occupants of both vehicles were brought to safety. ‚ÄúThe key advice is to consider whether your journey is necessary. ‚ÄúPlease avoid driving through any kind of standing or moving flood water if you possibly can.‚Äù Witnesses to the incident at Glaisdale are urged to call North Yorkshire Police on 101, option 4, quoting reference NYP-28122023-0146.

author: Sentinel Digital Desk
title: Assam: Landmark Peace Accord Signed with ULFA Pro-Talk Faction - Sentinelassam
text: Assam: Landmark Peace Accord Signed with ULFA Pro-Talk Faction Assam Chief Minister hails a historic peace accord with ULFA, ending decades-old insurgency. GUWAHATI: In a significant development for Assam, Chief Minister Himanta Biswa Sarma praised the recently signed tripartite peace accord with the United Liberation Front of Asom (ULFA) pro-talk faction, deeming it a historic milestone that will usher in lasting peace for the state. The accord, signed in New Delhi, was characterized by CM Sarma as the culmination of a peace process initiated in Assam under the leadership of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the guidance of Home Minister Amit Shah. Speaking at the signing ceremony, CM Sarma highlighted the broader context of the peace efforts, noting that similar accords had been reached with other insurgent groups in the state, including the Bodo, Karbi, and Adivasi factions. He emphasized that the agreement with the [ULFA ](https://www.sentinelassam.com/topheadlines/assam-army-goc-in-c-lt-gen-rp-kalita-urges-paresh-barua-to-return-683365)pro-talk faction would address the aspirations of the people of Assam, marking a transformative moment for the region. "This is a historic day for Assam. The process for peace has been on in Assam under the leadership of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the guidance of Home Minister Amit Shah. We signed accords with Bodo, Karbi, and Adivasi insurgent groups," stated CM Sarma, adding, "This agreement will fulfill many of the aspirations of the people of Assam. In general, PM Modi's outreach towards Assam and other parts of the northeast has made this possible." CM Sarma gave assurance that both the Central and State governments were committed to fully implementing the provisions outlined in the tripartite deal. He highlighted the participation of founding members of ULFA in the signing ceremony and conveyed their commitment to disband the organization, surrender arms, and integrate 726 cadres into the mainstream. The leaders of the pro-talk faction assured that they would cease all activities not by the law. The peace accord, long-awaited and aimed at ending decades-old insurgency in Assam, was signed in the presence of Union Home Minister Amit Shah and Chief Minister Himanta Biswa Sarma. The ULFA pro-talks delegation, comprising 16 ULFA members and 13 representatives from civil society, signed the agreement. The ULFA, formed in 1979 with the demand for a "sovereign Assam," had been involved in subversive activities, leading to its ban by the central government in 1990. The faction splintered in 2011, with one group, led by Arabinda Rajkhowa, renouncing violence for unconditional talks. The other faction, led by Paresh Baruah and renamed ULFA-Independent, remained opposed to negotiations. The historic tripartite peace accord holds the promise of transformative change for Assam, signaling an end to protracted insurgency and paving the way for a peaceful and prosperous future. ALSO READ: [Assam Legislative Assembly Gears Up for Pivotal Budget Session with Focus on Polygamy Debate](https://www.sentinelassam.com/north-east-india-news/assam-news/assam-legislative-assembly-gears-up-for-pivotal-budget-session-with-focus-on-polygamy-debate-683747) ALSO WATCH:

author: Greg Owen
title: ‚ÄúHabitual violent offender‚Äù arrested in gruesome death of trans woman in Miami Beach
text:
A transgender woman was brutally beaten to death in the early hours of Tuesday morning as she lay sleeping near the entrance to Miami City Ballet in South Beach.
A 53-year-old ‚Äúhabitual violent offender‚Äù was arrested later in the day, the Miami Herald reported.
Surveillance video reveals Andrea Doria Dos Passos, 37, whom police say was homeless, lying down outside the ballet's headquarters around midnight.
Hours later, a man identified as Gregory Fitzgerald Gibert, 53, can be seen looking intently at Dos Passos, walking away from her, and then picking up a metal pipe he finds on the ground. He takes a seat on a bench near the sleeping woman, then walks toward her and ‚Äúbegins to strike her with the metal pipe about the head and face several times,‚Äù according to a Miami Beach Police report.
After smashing Dos Passos' skull several times, Gibert can be seen walking from the scene and dropping the weapon in a nearby trashcan. Police discovered the pipe later that morning.
An employee at Miami City Ballet found Dos Passos' lifeless body around 7:00 am and tried to wake her. When he saw blood, he called 911.
Police report paramedics observed extensive lacerations on Dos Passos' face and the back of her head. Two wooden sticks were lodged into her nostrils.
‚ÄúOne stick exited over the right eye and the other appeared lodged into the nose cavity,‚Äù police detailed in Gibert's arrest report. ‚ÄúA puncture wound was also located in the victim‚Äôs chest.‚Äù
Police matched Gibert‚Äôs description to a previous mugshot and found him across Biscayne Bay in a rough neighborhood in Miami. He was wearing some of the same bloodstained clothing he had on during the attack.
Despite the brutal nature of the killing, a hallmark of violence against trans victims, Miami Beach Police Chief Wayne Jones said in a statement on Wednesday that the evidence did not indicate Dos Passos was the target of a hate crime.
‚ÄúAt this time, there is no evidence to suggest that Andrea was targeted because of her sexuality or gender,‚Äù Jones said. ‚ÄúHowever, we understand the concerns within the LGBTQIA+ community, and I want to emphasize that MBPD is committed to ensuring the safety and well-being of all our community members.‚Äù
Flamingo Democrats, the Miami-Dade chapter of Florida's LGBTQ+ Democratic Caucus, urged the state attorney‚Äôs office to add a hate crime enhancement to Gibert‚Äôs second-degree murder charge.
‚ÄúThe safety of all residents of Miami Beach and Miami-Dade County should be of the utmost importance, especially those in marginalized communities such as our transgender community,‚Äù the group said in a statement.
Gibert was on parole after a year-long stretch in Miami-Dade County Corrections awaiting trial on charges of aggravated assault and attempted robbery. He was released on April 17 with time served.
The alleged assailant earned the designation ‚Äúhabitual violent offender‚Äù with more than two dozen criminal cases in Florida since 2000, including aggravated assault, attempted robbery, gun charges, cocaine possession and resisting arrest.
Gibert was booked into a Miami-Dade County jail, where he remains.
‚ÄúShe had no chance to defend herself whatsoever,‚Äù Dos Passos‚Äôs stepfather, Victor Van Gilst, told CBS News in Miami.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if this was a hate crime since she was transgender or if she had some sort of interaction with this person because he might have been homeless as well," Van Gilst said. "She has been struggling with mental health issues for a long time, going back to when she was in her early 20s."
For Dos Passos' mother, Van Gilst added, "This is like a nightmare that turned into reality."
